title: Experimental
content: Melamine (Merck, 99.99 ) for synthesis of g-C3N4, Bentonite (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99 ), titanium aluminum carbide (Ti3AlC2, 98, 200 mesh, Famouschem China) for the synthesis of Ti3C2, methanol (Merck, 99.99) and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 49 , Emplura) are the materials and chemicals used in this study. The Ti3C2 MXenes nanosheets were synthesized through etching of Ti3AlC2 with HF in a continuous stirred tank reactor.Typically, 1 g of Ti3AlC2 (powder) was dispersed in a 20 mL HF solution (content 49 ) and suspension was transferred into Teflon lined stainless steel reactor and stirred for 24 h to get Ti3C2 MXenes.The suspension obtained was centrifuged and washed with DI water until pH 6.The product obtained was dried at 100 o C for 24 in an oven under airflow and named as Ti3C2 MXenes nanosheets.The Ti3C2 MXenes with in-situ growth of TiO2 NPs was achieved by increasing etching time to 96 h and named as Ti3C2Tx Mxenes nanosheets. The g-C3N4 was prepared using melamine as the precursor through hydrothermal approach according to our previous report 10.First, melamine (10 g) was placed in a ceramic crucible, covered with lid and heated in a furnace at 550 o C for 2 h under air atmosphere.After cooling, yellowish color bulk cake obtained was grinded to fine powder using mortar and pestle.Then, the powder was added into 40 mL (1M) nitric acid solution and stirred for next 24 h.The suspension obtained was centrifuged and washed with water to remove impurities and to get pH 7.Finally, sample obtained was dried at 100 o C overnight and named as graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets (g-C3N4). The g-C3N4/Bt, g-C3N4/Ti3C2 MXene and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 MXene composite samples were prepared through ultrasonic approach at normal temperature.First, g-C3N4 (1 g) was dispersed into 20 mL methanol and stirred for 6 h to get uniform dispersion of g-C3N4 nanosheets (sample A). Second, specific amount of bentonite (Bt) was added to 20 mL methanol under stirring and ultrasonic for 60 min to get exfoliated Bt nanosheets (sample B).Third, Ti3C2 added in 20 mL methanol was dispersed through ultrasonic to get exfoliated Ti3C2 layers (sample C).In the next stage, Bt suspension (sample B) was added to g-C3N4 suspension (sample A) and stirred for 6 h with ultrasonic for 60 min to get good interface interaction of g-C3N4 with Bt (sample D).The sample obtained was centrifuged and dried at 100 o C for 24 h and named as 2D/2D g-C3N4/Bt composite.Similarly, for the synthesis of g-C3N4/Ti3C2 MXene composite, the Ti3C2 (sample C) suspension was added to g-C3N4 suspension (sample A) under continuous stirring.The product obtained was oven dried at 100 o C under air flow and named as 2D/2D g-C3N4/Ti3C2 MXene composite.Finally, g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 MXene composite was synthesized using the similar method as discussed above.Firstly, g-C3N4 solution (sample A) was mixed with Bt suspension (sample B) to get homogenous dispersion of both the samples (sample D).Afterwards, specific amount of Ti3C2 dispersed in methanol (sample C) was added to mixture of g-C3N4/Bt (sample D) under stirring.The sample was further ultrasonic for 60 min to get good dispersion of nanosheets and finally centrifuged to remove methanol.The sludge obtained was dried for 24 h at 100 o C and named a 2D/2D/2D g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 MXene composite nanosheets.The scheme for the synthesis of 2D/2D/2D g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 MXene composite has been demonstrated in Fig. 1. Schematic illustration for the synthesis process of functionalized g-C3N4, Ti3C2 through HF etching, exfoliated Bt and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite samples. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained through advance spectrometer (Bruker D8) operated at 40 kV and 40 mA.Raman shift peaks were identified using HORIBA Scientific spectrophotometer with laser wavelength 532 nm.Morphology of the samples was evaluated using Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi SU8020 instrument).EDX (Energy-dispersive X-ray) spectroscopy mapping analysis was conducted to identify elements distribution over the catalyst with their composition.Similarly, High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) images were collected to identify materials structure through HITACHI HT7700 machine.X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) (Axis Ultra DLD instrument) was employed to determine elemental state of the samples.Ultraviolet visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-Vis DRS) were obtained using Cary 100 Agilent spectrophotometer integrated with sphere for powder sample analysis.Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained using HORIBA spectrometer operated at wavelength 325 nm.The thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted with air flow rate of 200 mL min -1 and heating rate of 2 C/min and 10-900 C. The performance analysis of photocatalysts was conducted in a fixed bed photoreactor operated under visible light irradiation.The source of light was a 35 W HID lamp with a maximum light intensity 20 mW cm -2 with wavelength 420 nm.The experiments were conducted with and without UV-cut filters located above the glass window and their effects on catalyst performance and products selectivity were evaluated.A solar concentrator was used to simulate light irradiations from the lamp towards the catalyst surface.The reactor was fixed with a glass window of thickness 10 mm and lamp integrated with a concentrator mirror was located 5 cm above the glass window. First, 150 mg powder catalyst was uniformly distributed at the reactor bottom and then nitrogen (N2) gas was passed through the reactor to remove air and other impurities from the reactor. Second, high purity CO2 (99.99), regulated by mass flow controller (MFC), was bubbled through the water saturator to carry moisture and was flowing through the reactor for 30 min to saturate the catalyst and to purge the reactor system.All the experiments were conducted under reactor pressure of 0.20 bars above the atmospheric pressure.The CO2/H2O feed ratio was varied using different temperature of water saturator (e.g., 15, 30 and 45 o C), while kept constant CO2 flow rate (20 mL min -1 ) in all the experiments.Similarly, for the investigation of acetic acid effect on the catalyst performance, acetic acid (10 vol.) was added to water saturator and CO2 gas (20 ml min -1 ) was bubbled through the water-acetic acid aqueous solution.All the experiments were conducted without providing external heat.Online GC-TCD/FID (GC-Agilent Technologies 6890 N, USA) was used for the analysis of reaction products.In addition, CARBOXEN 1010 plot column was connected with TCD and FID detectors for the separation of CO, H2, CO2 and CH4 gases. title: Results_and_Discussion
content: To determine etching of Ti3AlC2 and formation process of Ti3C2 at different times, XRD analysis was conducted and results are demonstrated in Fig. 2 typical layered structure of Bt.When Bt and Ti3C2 were combined with g-C3N4 to construct g-C3N4/Bt and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2, all the original peaks were appeared, indexed to g-C3N4, Bt and Ti3C2, confirming successful formation of composite catalyst. The Raman analysis was further conducted to identify interaction among the elements in the composite sample and the results are demonstrated in Fig. 2 (c).The g-C3N4 peaks appeared at 323, 478, 588, 707, 765, 979, 1116, 1232, 1312, 1481 and 1619 cm -1 confirmed graphitic structure of carbon nitride.The Raman peaks at 478, 707 and 1232 cm 1 can be ascribed to vibration of the tri-s-triazine ring.The obvious peaks appeared at 702 and 979 cm -1 evidenced the presence of heptazine ring structure.For the Raman spectra of pristine Bt strong bands in the range of 200 to 400 cm -1 were observed.The band appeared at 395 cm -1 can be ascribed to v3(a1) internal vibration mode of SiO4 tetrahedron units.Similarly, band appeared at 281 cm -1 was probably due to v1(A1) O-H-O unit.The band at 215 cm -1 was due to v1(A1g) vibrational mode of AlO6 octahedron unit. Similarly, 1, 1, 2, 3 and 4 modes of Ti3AlC2 phase were appeared at 254, 418, 608 and 713 cm -1 , attributed to MAX structure.However, two peaks appeared at 1480, 1621 cm -1 in g-C3N4 and 1367, 1585 cm -1 in Ti3AlC2, ascribed to the presence of D-band and G band of carbon in both the samples, respectively.Furthermore, obvious bands in Ti3C2 at 400 cm -1 and 622 cm -1 could be ascribed to the presence of TiO2 over the nanosheets.However, bands at 1343 and 1570 cm -1 ascribed to D and G bands of carbon in Ti3C2 sample.Furthermore, all the peaks of g-C3N4, Bt and Ti3C2 appeared in the composite of g-C3N4/Bt and g-C3N4/Ti3C2 and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite samples.This confirms successful fabrication of composite catalyst with their good interaction and would be promising to maximize catalytic activity and products selectivity. The morphology of g-C3N4, bentonite (Bt), Ti3AlC2, Ti3C2 and their composites has been demonstrated in Fig. 3. Obviously, g-C3N4 has layered compact sheets as shown in Fig. 3 (a). Similarly, exfoliated 2D sheets of Bt are obvious in Fig. 3 (b).Fig. 3 (c) presents Ti3AlC2 structure with compact sheets.After etching with HF for 24 h, single layer Ti2C2 sheets were obtained as illustrated in Fig. 3 (d-e).Furthermore, when etching process was extended to 96 h, a controlled growth of TiO2 NPs over the Ti3C2 nanosheets was obtained as demonstrated in Fig. 3 (f).Fig. 3 (g) shows g-C3N4/Bt composite morphology, in which, obvious heterojunction between g-C3N4 and Bt could be seen.This confirms successful formation of g-C3N4/Bt composite through ultrasonic approach.The fabrication of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite has been further illustrated in Fig. 3 (h-i).It is obvious that g-C3N4/Bt composite has good interface interaction with Ti3C2 nanosheets, thus developing 2D/2D/2D heterojunction between all the three materials and similarly reported in literature 36.It is predictable that close interaction between Bt, Ti3C2 and g-C3N4 will provide more electron transfer pathways and would be beneficial for electron transfer and separation 37.To further investigate the elements distribution in the composite sample, EDX mapping analysis was conducted as demonstrated in Fig. 3 (j-k).Fig. 3 (j) demonstrates uniform distribution of elements over the composite catalyst.However, EDX plot in Fig. 3 (k) further confirms the present of all the elements in the composite catalyst.Therefore, successful fabrication of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite can be obtained through etching of Ti3AlC2 to get Ti3C2 and ultrasonic exfoliation of materials. TEM analysis was further conducted to identify structure and morphology of g-C3N4, Ti3AlC2, g-C3N4/Bt, and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite samples.As shown in Fig. 4 (a) polymeric structure of g-C3N4 with compact 2D nanosheets are obvious.Similarly, Fig. 4 (b) shows 2D sheets of Ti3AlC2, in which, all the sheets are stacked together to give bulk MAX structure of compact sheets.TEM images in Fig. 4 (c-e) clearly illustrates formation of heterojunction among the g-C3N4, Bt and Ti3C2 samples.It is worth mentioned that Ti3C2 keeps layered structure after ultra-sonication, confirming good stability of exfoliated monolayers.HRTEM images in Fig. 4 (f-h) further confirms good interaction among all the components to construct 2D/2D/2D heterojunction of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite, which is in accordance with the similar work 33,38.More importantly, TiO2 NPs grown over the Ti3C2 sheets could be seen under high magnification.The identification of g-C3N4, TiO2, Bt and Ti3C2 was further conducted through diffraction analysis and similarly reported in the literature 39.As demonstrated in Fig. 4 (i-m), 0.346, 0.33, 0.266 and 0.282 nm d-spacing for TiO2, g-C3N4, Ti3C2 and Bt, respectively, were obtained, confirming successful formation of composite heterojunction with good interaction.All the results of electron microscopy are well consistent with the above XRD and Raman analysis.Therefore, successful fabrication of 2D/2D/2D g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 heterojunction with large interfacial contacts would be beneficial for efficient photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The surface chemical composition was calculated using XPS and the results are presented in Fig. 5.As depicted in Fig. 5 respectively 40.The two peaks at 453.1 and 460.2 eV can be ascribed to Ti-C 2p3/2 and Ti-C 2p1/2, respectively, whereas, other two peaks at 457.5 and 465.1 eV revel the existence of Ti-O 2p3/2 and Ti-O 2p1/2, respectively 37,41.Fig. 5 (c) demonstrates N 1s spectra of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite samples.For pristine g-C3N4, peaks located at 398.8 and 400.2 eV are relating to C-NC and N-C3, respectively.However, additional peak positioned at 407.1 eV was due to surface charge modification of g-C3N4 and confirmed the charging effects in g-C3N4 surface.Furthermore, g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite demonstrated several peaks with binding energies 298.5, 399.9, 403.7 and 406.5 eV, can be assigned to C-NC, N-C3, C-NH and charging effects due to surface modification, respectively 27.The XPS analysis of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 for O 1s has been demonstrated in Fig. 5 (d).For pristine g-C3N4, peaks appeared at 532.8 eV can be assigned to adsorbed oxygen.However, O 1s spectra of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 demonstrated several peaks with binding energies 529.8, 531.3, 532.4,533.5 and 534.6 eV, relating to Ti-O, Ti-OH, adsorbed O2 and atomic O2 due to surface oxygen vacancies, respectively.Fig. 5 (e-f The optical absorption properties of g-C3N4, Ti3C2, Bt and their composites were studied using UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) and results are demonstrated in Fig. 6 (a).Pristine Ti3C2 MXene shows an enhanced visible light absorption due to black color nature.Previously, fullspectrum light absorption characteristics in the whole range with displaying no obvious absorption peak by Ti3C2 MXene has been reported by several researchers 37,42.Similarly, Bt has light absorption under visible and UV light irradiation.The g-C3N4 presents visible light absorption with wavelength above 400 nm.When, Bt is combined with g-C3N4, there was no significant effect on the band edge shift and visible light absorption of g-C3N4.Similarly, there was no effect on the band-edge shift of g-C3N4 by coupling with Ti3C2MXene.By constructing 2D/2D/2D heterojunction of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite, similar trends were obtained with no band edge shift of g-C3N4.The Tauc plot was used to calculate band gap energy via the Kubelka-Munk method. The band gap energies calculated were 2.78, 2.82, 2.83 and 2.81 eV for g-C3N4, g-C3N4/Bt, g-C3N4/Ti3C2 and g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2, respectively.This reveals that there was no significant effect in the change of band gap energy with Bt and Ti3C2 loading with g-C3N4.Previously, Yang et al 38 reported the synthesis of 2D/2D Ti3C2/g-C3N4 heterojunction with g-C3N4 band gap of 2.80 eV, whereas, loading Ti3C2 into g-C3N4 demonstrates a negligible effect on altering band gap energy of Ti3C2/g-C3N4 compared to pristine g-C3N4.It was illustrated that introducing Ti3C2 does not change bang gap energy of g-C3N4, but light absorption ability of Ti3C2/g-C3N4 in the visible region has been enhanced, due to dark color of Ti3C2.Therefore, higher visible light absorption of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite in the presence of Bt and Ti3C2 would be beneficial for promoting photocatalytic activity. Furthermore, wide spectra of g-C3N4 was used to calculate valance band position as demonstrated in Fig. 6 (b).The VB of 1.48 eV was obtained for the pristine g-C3N4, which is further used to calculate conduction band (CB) position of g-C3N4 using Eq. ( 5). Using band gap energy of 2.78 eV and VB of 1.48, g-C3N4 CB of -1.30 eV is obtained.The results of current study have good agreement to the values reported in the literature.For example, CB positions of -1.35 and -1.26 eV and VB positions of 1.45 and 1.54 eV have been reported for g-C3N4 and Ti3C2/g-C3N4 composite, respectively 38.This shows g-C3N4 has more negative conduction band position and would be beneficial for stimulating photocatalytic CO2 reduction process under visible light irradiation. The photoluminescence (PL) analysis was further conducted to determine the effect of Bt and Ti3C2 on the charges separation of g-C3N4 and the results are demonstrated in Fig. 6 (c).The PL analysis was conducted using 325 nm wavelength and peaks were appeared between 450 to 500 nm for all the samples.Pristine g-C3N4 shows highest PL intensity due to the faster charges recombination rate.The PL intensity of g-C3N4 was obviously decreased with Bt loading, which confirms its function as a mediator and prevents charges recombination in the Bt/g-C3N4 composite.Similarly, addition of Ti3C2 traps electrons and improves separation efficiency, resulting in lowest PL intensity in the g-C3N4/Ti3C2 composite.This decreased in PL intensity was obviously due to good interaction between g-C3N4 and Ti3C2 2D/2D heterojunction, thus, preventing charges recombination rate due to a good conductivity of Ti3C2.Previously, it has been reported that coupling Ti3C2 with g-C3N4 to construct hybrid structure, remarkably drops charges recombination rate.This reveals that Ti3C2 effectively restrained recombination of photo-induced charge carriers and boosts electron separation and transfer due to its metallic characteristics and higher electrical conductivity 33,37.More importantly, much higher charges separation efficiency was achieved in Bt and Ti3C2 loaded g-C3N4 composite sample.This was obviously due to multiple electrons separation channels in the presence of Bt and Ti3C2 because of many intimate interface contacts formation among the three phases.Thus, successful development of 2D/2D/2D g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite with faster charges separation was obtained and would be beneficial for stimulating photocatalytic CO2 reduction efficiency. The performance analysis of different materials was estimated by photocatalytic CO2 reduction to solar fuels using H2O as the reducing agent under visible light irradiation.The light source with and without UV-cut filters was further employed to understand the role of grown TiO2 over the monolayers of Ti3C2 nanosheets.Similarly, water with acetic acid as the sacrificial agent to promote methane formation was further explored.Initially, quality tests were conducted under two conditions: first reaction was conducted using pure nitrogen gas in the presence of catalyst and light irradiation; second, feed mixture (CO2, H2O) was used without catalyst under light irradiations.In both the cases, production of CO or CH4 were not identified in the products mixture, which confirms that catalyst is clean and any carbon containing compounds were originated during CO2 reduction in the presence of catalyst and light irradiation. The photocatalytic activity of different catalysts for the production of CO and CH4 during photoreduction of CO2 with water under visible light irradiation is presented in Fig. 7.As depicted in Fig. 7 (a) carbon monoxide (CO) is the main CO2 reduction product accompanied by appreciable amount of methane (CH4) production.Using pristine g-C3N4, a weak photoactivity with CO and CH4 evolution rate of 76 and 33 mole g-cat -1 h -1 , respectively were produced.This was obviously due to faster recombination of photo-generated electrons (e -) and holes (h ) pairs.Increasing photoactivity of g-C3N4 was obtained after coupling with Bt to construct 2D/2D g-C3N4/Bt heterojunction.Using g-C3N4/Bt composite, CO evolution rate of 285 mole g-cat -1 h -1 was observed, a 3.75-fold higher than using pristine g-C3N4 sheets.This obvious enhancement was due to the formation of 2D/2D interaction, enabling superior charges separation and their transportation within the catalyst surface.Previously, we investigated montmorillonite (Mt) clay dispersed TiO2 composites for photocatalytic CO2 reduction and water splitting applications and witnessed similar outcomes 43,44.Therefore, significantly enhanced photoactivity was apparently due to good interaction between g-C3N4 and Bt with superior charge carrier separation due to layered structure of Bt, resulting in efficient photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO and CH4. In order to understand the influence of 2D Ti3AlC2 MAX and 2D Ti3C2 MXene on the photoactivity of g-C3N4 for photocatalytic CO2 reduction with H2O, different samples such as 2D Ti3AlC2 MAX/g-C3N4 and 2D Ti3C2 MXenes/g-C3N4 composites samples were constructed.As shown in Fig. 7 (a), a 2D MAX supported g-C3N4 showed CO evolution rate of 227 mole g-cat -1 h -1 , which is 2.98 folds higher than using pristine g-C3N4.This substantial improvement in the g-C3N4 activity towards CO evolution rate was obviously due to Ti3AlC2 conductive properties, resulting in boosted charge carrier separation.However, when 2D Ti3C2 MXene exfoliated layers were employed in the composite of g-C3N4, CO evolution rate reached to 313 mole g-cat -1 h -1 , which is 4.12-fold more than using g-C3N4 under the same reaction parameters.Thus, 2D/2D g-C3N4/Ti3C2 MXene found very efficient to promote CO2 reduction efficiency due to Ti3C2 conductive nature, enabling proficient migration and separation of electron and hole pairs for CO2 reduction and water oxidation under light irradiation.Previously, we reported photocatalytic CO2 reduction over Cu-loaded CNTs/g-C3N4 and CO was identified as the main product over the entire irradiation time 45.Similarly, enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO and CH4 over 2D/2D Ti3AlC2 dispersed pg-C3N4 has been reported under visible light irradiations 46. In order to investigate the role of Bt and Ti3C2 as cocatalyst on the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4, photocatalytic CO2 reduction experiments for CO and CH4 production were conducted over 2D/2D/2D g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 MXene composite under visible light irradiation.As shown in Fig. 7 (a), pure g-C3N4 and binary composites of Bt/g-C3N4 and g-C3N4/Ti3C2 found efficient for selective CO2 reduction to CO, however, g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite found encouraging to stimulate both CO and CH4 evolution.As expected photocatalytic CO evolution of 326 mole gcat -1 h -1 was achieved over g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 MXene composite, nearly 1.04, 1.43, 1.14 and 4.29 times more than using g-C3N4/Ti3C2, g-C3N4/Ti3AlC2, g-C3N4/Bt and g-C3N4 composite samples, respectively.The Ti3C2 serves as a Schottky junction with g-C3N4 and Bt serves as an electron mediator, resulting in efficient separation of photo-induced electrons, which is crucial in photocatalytic CO2 reduction applications.Notably, CH4 evolution rate of 230 mole g-cat -1 h -1 was obtained over the ternary g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite sample, which is nearly 4.18, 4.42, 16.17, 4.18 times more than using g-C3N4/Ti3C2, g-C3N4/Ti3AlC2, g-C3N4/Bt and g-C3N4 samples, respectively.This enhanced photoactivity over g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite towards selective methane formation was obviously due to more production of electrons with superior separation and transformation to provide sufficient electrons density within the heterostructure of the composite catalyst for transforming CO2 to CH4.Previously, enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction with H2O to CH4 over the carbon implanted SnS2 under visible light has been reported 47.The photoactivity of catalyst for CH4 production was increased due to higher CO2 adsorption over the C-SnS2 active sites, noticeable charge transfer between Sn and S together with C, resulting in availability of electrons density to activate CO2 over the catalyst surface. Relatively, 2D Ti3C2 MXene found more efficient for migration and separation of charge carrier compared with Ti3AlC2 MAX structure.The CO evolved over the 2D/2D g-C3N4/Ti3C2 MXene composite was 1.38-fold higher than using 2D/2D g-C3N4/Ti3AlC2 MAX composite.These findings could be explained based on the conductive properties and their interfacial interaction with g-C3N4 to construct a good heterojunction.First, Ti3AlC2 is less conductive compared to Ti3C2 due to the presence of Al in the MAX structure.Thus, charges separation in Ti3AlC2/g-C3N4 would be less proficient than using g-C3N4/Ti3C2 MXene composite.Second, interaction between Ti3AlC2/g-C3N4 is not good compared to Ti3C2/g-C3N4 composite as demonstrated in Fig. 7 (b c).As demonstrated in Fig. 7 (b), Ti3AlC2 has compact sheets to give bulk structure and g-C3N4 can only be distributed over the bulk surface, resulting in poor interaction between 2D Ti3AlC2 and 2D g-C3N4.Thus, charges produced over the g-C3N4 has more potential to recombine, compared to transfer towards Ti3AlC2, resulting in lower activity during CO2 reduction process. Comparatively, Ti3C2 has exfoliated layers structure and g-C3N4 has been intimate interface interaction over the individual layered structure as demonstrated in Fig. 7 (c).Therefore, 2D Ti3C2 has good interaction with 2D g-C3N4 to construct 2D/2D heterojunction with superior charge carrier separation.Under visible light irradiation, photo-generated electrons over the g-C3N4 surface can proficiently be separated, resulting in enhanced CO2 reduction to methane under visible light irradiation.Previously, photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO over Z-scheme g-C3N4/Bi2O2 BO2(OH) has been investigated under visible light irradiation 48.It was observed that compared to mechanically-mixed g-C3N4 synthesis approach, ball milling method provides an intimate interface interaction between g-C3N4 and Bi2O2 BO2(OH), thus exhibits more efficient photocatalytic performance.This further confirms that interaction among the materials is very promising to maximize photocatalytic activity towards enhanced CO2 reduction. According to thermodynamics, 2 electrons are required for CO2 reduction to CO, compared to 8 electrons for the methane production.Due to good interaction among Bt, Ti3C2 and g-C3N4, a 2D/2D/2D heterojunction is developed, providing a good interfacial charge transfer potential. Thus, more production of electrons and their transforming for CO2 reduction, enabling more production of CH4.This phenomenon is further illustrated in thermodynamic analysis and reaction mechanism sections.Previously, enhanced CO2 reduction to CO over 2D/2D Ti3C2 MXene/g-C3N4 nanosheets heterojunction for high efficient photocatalytic CO2 reduction has been investigated 38.In another development, 1D CdS nanorods/2D Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets for enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen production was obtained 42.Similarly, g-C3N4/Ti3C2 with enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO has been reported due to superior charge carrier separation 49.Enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO and CH4 over TiO2 coupled with surfacealkalinized titanium carbide MXene as co-catalyst has been investigated 50.2D/2D heterojunction of MXene/Bi2WO6 with enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CH4 and CH3OH was obtained 51.Similarly, production of CO with smaller amount of CH4 was obtained over g-C3N4 However, production of CH4 was obviously increased, when C3N4 was coupled with Ti3C2, due to more production of charge carrier and their proficient separation over the conductive Ti3C2 surface.Highest CO and CH4 amounts were obtained when 2D/2D/0D TiO2/C3N4/Ti3C2 composite heterojunction photocatalyst was constructed 52.Thus, constructing 2D heterojunction of g-C3N4 with 2D/2D Ti3C2/Bt is promising to maximize catalytic activity due to proficient migration and transportation of charge carrier because of good interface interaction, more CO2 uptake and high light absorption under visible light irradiation. The light source has a significant contribution to alter the performance of photocatalyst, g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite catalyst was further evaluated under different visible light sources and results are demonstrated in Fig. 8 (a).Obviously, productions trends of CO and CH4 are different using visible light irradiations under UV-cut filters (420 nm) and without filters.Using UV-cut filter, lower amount of CH4 was produced, which was significantly increased under visible light irradiation without UV-filters.The CH4 evolution of 101 mol g-cat -1 was obtained under UV-cut filters, which was increased by 4.6 folds higher (460 mol g-cat -1 ) without UV-cut filters. Similarly, production of CO was increased by 1.3 folds higher without UV-cut filters.These findings could be explained based on the availability of total light intensity (UV and visible light) for photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction.Furthermore, during controlled HF etching of Ti3AlC2, TiO2 NPs were produced, thus, it can be activated by the light irradiations, producing electrons and holes.The photogenerated electrons from CB of TiO2 (-0.52 eV) would be transferred towards VB of g-C3N4, enabling their efficient separation.However, this mechanism would be limited compared to g-C3N4 activation due to the presence of only small portion of TiO2 NPs over the Ti3C2 surface. According to thermodynamics, 8 electrons are required for CO2 reduction to CH4 compared to only 2 electrons involvement for CO production.When UV-cut filters were employed, light intensity was also reduced, whereas, only g-C3N4 was activated for the production of charge carriers.In this case, lower number of electrons would be generated, resulting in production of CO as the major product.Conversely, when visible light without UV-cut flirters was employed, light intensity would be increased, whereas, it has potential to activate g-C3N4 and TiO2 NPs produced over the Ti3C2 layers, resulting in more production of electrons.Due to proficient production of charge carriers, CO2 was effectively converted to CO and CH4 with the involvement of 2 and 8 electrons, respectively.Besides, CO would also be converted to CH4 with the utilization of 6 electrons, resulting in more production of methane.Previously, MoS2 and Ti3C2 MXene as cocatalyst for enhanced photoactivity of TiO2 for photocatalytic hydrogen production has been reported 53.Thus, a mixture of UV and visible light is more promising to maximize CO2 reduction efficiency towards selective methane production due to more production of electrons and holes. During photocatalysis, uptake of CO2 and water should be attached to catalyst active sites for proficient reduction and oxidation process.With feed temperature of 15 o C, higher CO2/H2O feed ratio in reactor system, resulting in more amount of CO2 attached to catalyst surface compared to water.Under such conditions, majority of the active sites are occupied by the CO2 molecules, whereas water molecules have to compete with CO2 for the adsorption.Thus, amount of water attached to catalyst surface would not be enough to carry proficient oxidation process, resulting in lower production of protons (H ) and more charge carrier recombination.However, when temperature was increased to 45 o C, lower CO2/H2O feed ratio was achieved.This shows, water vapor rich CO2 feed mixture was passed through reactor to saturate the catalyst surface.Under such condition, there would be more attachment of water molecules with catalyst active sites, resulting in lower photo-activity.This was obviously, CO2 has to compete with water molecules for its adsorption, and if lower amount of CO2 is attached with catalyst surface, reduction reaction would be slowed down, resulting in lower efficiency.Highest amount of CO and CH4 were produced at temperature 30 o C, probably both CO2 and H2O would be attached to catalyst surface, resulting in proficient oxidation and reduction reaction with lower charge carrier recombination rate. reported in the literature 38,61.It could be seen that the production of CH4 requires 8 electrons and 8 protons during CO2 reduction process compared to only 2 electrons and 2 protons needed for CO production.Due to fast recombination of photogenerated charges over the pristine g-C3N4, very weak photocatalytic CO2 reduction over g-C3N4 with smaller amounts of methane was obtained.However, highest production of methane was obtained over the g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite catalyst due to combined effects of Bt and Ti3C2 for preventing charges recombination and providing multiple electron separation pathways for the conversion of CO2 and CO to CH4.Previously, Ti2C/TiO2/M has been reported with enhanced photocatalytic activity due to superior interfacial charge transfer separation from TiO2 towards Ti2C and M in multiple electron separation channels 62.Besides, in the presence of acetic acid, there would be more production of protons (H ) compared to using only water, thus it would be beneficial for transforming more CO2 into CO and finally to CH4.This confirms proficient production of electrons and protons over the composite catalyst enabling more production of methane under visible light irradiation.Therefore, controlled synthesis of 2D/2D/2D heterojunction of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 with excellent electron trapping and transporting ability make composite a superior catalyst for photocatalytic methane production under visible light irradiation.

title: Conclusions
content: A new 2D/2D/2D heterojunction of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite was successfully fabricated using HF etching approach, which shows significantly improved efficiency towards photocatalytic CO2 conversion under visible light.The analysis of g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composite demonstrates selective CH4 production using CO2-water reaction system, whereas, single Bt and Ti3C2 loaded samples promoted CO evolution rate.When acetic acid as the sacrificial reagent was used, production of CH4 was significantly enhanced under the same reaction conditions.The CH4 production over g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 composited was 4.15, 17.36 and 28.93 folds higher than using g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2, g-C3N4/Ti3C2 and g-C3N4 samples, respectively.Similarly, a selectivity of 72.35 was obtained over g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 for CH4 evolution, while it was 41.37, 14.95 and 30.28 over g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2, g-C3N4/Ti3C2 and g-C3N4, respectively, using CO2-water reaction system.This selective photocatalytic CO2 conversion to CH4 suggests that g-C3N4/Bt/Ti3C2 is a promising material and can be further explored in solar energy applications.The stability test revealed continuous CO and CH4 evolution in cycles.The thermodynamics analysis elucidates, CO2 was first converted to CO before the production of CH4 and water is oxidized to hydrogen under light irradiation.These encourages results and new findings would be useful for further investigation in this field for wastewater and solar energy applications. CO2/H2O feed-ratio and UV-visible light greatly contributed for CO2 reduction to CH4. High stability and reusability in cycles was attained using 2D Ti3C2/Bt with g-C3N4 catalyst.
